# Z1 (computer)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Zuse_Z1-2.jpg/220px-
Zuse_Z1-2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zuse_Z1-2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Zuse_Z1-2.jpg "Enlarge")

Replica of the Z1 in the [German Museum of
Technology](/wiki/German_Museum_of_Technology_\(Berlin\) "German Museum of
Technology \(Berlin\)") in Berlin

The **Z1** was a mechanical [computer](/wiki/Computer "Computer") designed by
[Konrad Zuse](/wiki/Konrad_Zuse "Konrad Zuse") from 1935 to 1936 and built by
him from 1936 to 1938.[1][2] It was a binary electrically driven mechanical
calculator with limited programmability, reading instructions from punched
celluloid film.

The Z1 was the first freely programmable computer in the world which used
[Boolean logic](/wiki/Boolean_logic "Boolean logic") and binary [floating-
point numbers](/wiki/Floating-point_numbers "Floating-point numbers"), however
it was unreliable in operation.[3][4] It was completed in 1938 and financed
completely from private funds. This computer was destroyed in the bombardment
of Berlin in December 1943, during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World
War II"), together with all construction plans.

The Z1 was the first in a series of computers that Zuse designed. Its original
name was "V1" for VersuchsModell 1 (meaning Experimental Model 1). After WW2,
it was renamed "Z1" to differentiate from the [flying
bombs](/wiki/V-1_flying_bomb "V-1 flying bomb") designed by [Robert
Lusser](/wiki/Robert_Lusser "Robert Lusser").[5] The
[Z2](/wiki/Z2_\(computer\) "Z2 \(computer\)") and [Z3](/wiki/Z3_\(computer\)
"Z3 \(computer\)") were follow-ups based on many of the same ideas as the Z1.

## Design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Z1_\(computer\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Design")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Zuse_Patent_907948.jpg/220px-
Zuse_Patent_907948.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zuse_Patent_907948.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Zuse_Patent_907948.jpg "Enlarge")

Diagrams from Zuse's May 1936 patent for a binary switching element using a
mechanism of flat sliding rods. The Z1 was based on such elements.

The Z1 contained almost all the parts of a modern computer, i.e. control unit,
memory, micro sequences, [floating-point](/wiki/Floating-point "Floating-
point") logic and input–output devices. The Z1 was freely programmable via
punched tape and a punched tape reader.[6] There was a clear separation
between the punched tape reader, the control unit for supervising the whole
machine and the execution of the instructions, the arithmetic unit, and the
input and output devices. The input tape unit read perforations in
35-millimeter film.[7]

The Z1 was a 22-bit [floating-point](/wiki/Floating-point "Floating-point")
value adder and subtracter, with some control logic to make it capable of more
complex operations such as multiplication (by repeated additions) and division
(by repeated subtractions). The Z1's [instruction set](/wiki/Instruction_set
"Instruction set") had nine instructions and it took between one and twenty
[cycles per instruction](/wiki/Cycles_per_instruction "Cycles per
instruction").

The Z1 had a 64-word floating-point memory, where each word of memory could be
read from – and written to – by the control unit. The mechanical memory units
were unique in their design and were patented by Konrad Zuse in 1936. The
machine was only capable of executing instructions while reading from the
[punched tape](/wiki/Punched_tape "Punched tape") reader, so the program
itself was not loaded in its entirety into internal memory in advance.

The input and output were in decimal numbers, with a decimal exponent and the
units had special machinery for converting these to and from binary numbers.
The input and output instructions would be read or written as floating-point
numbers. The program tape was 35 mm film with the instructions encoded in
punched holes.

##
Construction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Z1_\(computer\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Construction")]

"Z1 was a machine of about 1000 kg weight, which consisted from some 20000
parts. It was a programmable computer, based on binary floating-point numbers
and a binary switching system. It consisted completely of thin metal sheets,
which Zuse and his friends produced using a jigsaw."[8] "The [data] input
device was a keyboard...The Z1’s programs (Zuse called them Rechenpläne) were
stored on punch tapes by means of an 8-bit code"[8]

Construction of the Z1 was privately financed. Zuse got money from his
parents, his sister Lieselotte, some students of the fraternity _AV Motiv_
(cf. [Helmut Schreyer](/wiki/Helmut_Schreyer "Helmut Schreyer")) and Kurt
Pannke (a calculating machines manufacturer in Berlin) to do so.

Zuse constructed the Z1 in his parents' apartment; in fact, he was allowed to
use the living room for his construction. In 1936, Zuse quit his job in
airplane construction in order to build the Z1.

Zuse is said to have used "thin metal strips" and perhaps "metal cylinders" or
glass plates to construct Z1. There were probably no commercial relays in it
(although the Z3 is said to have used a few telephone relays). The only
electrical unit was an electric motor to give the [clock
frequency](/wiki/Clock_frequency "Clock frequency") of 1 [Hz](/wiki/Hertz
"Hertz") (cycle per second) to the machine.

'The memory was constructed from thin strips of slotted metal and small pins,
and proved faster, smaller, and more reliable, than relays. The Z2 used the
mechanical memory of the Z1, but used relay-based arithmetic. The Z3 was
experimentally built entirely of relays. The Z4 was the first attempt at a
commercial computer, reverting to the faster and more economical mechanical
slotted metal strip memory, with relay processing, of the Z2, but the war
interrupted the Z4 development.'[9]

The Z1 was never very reliable in operation due to poor synchronization due to
internal and external stresses on the mechanical parts.

##
Reconstruction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Z1_\(computer\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Reconstruction")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Zuse_Z1.jpg/220px-
Zuse_Z1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zuse_Z1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Zuse_Z1.jpg "Enlarge")

Reconstruction of Z1

The original Z1 was destroyed by the [Allied air raids in
1943](/wiki/Bombing_of_Berlin_in_World_War_II "Bombing of Berlin in World War
II"), but in 1986 Zuse decided to rebuild the machine. He constructed
thousands of elements of the Z1 again, and finished rebuilding the device in
1989. The rebuilt Z1 (pictured) is displayed at the [German Museum of
Technology](/wiki/German_Museum_of_Technology "German Museum of Technology")
in Berlin.

## Quotation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Z1_\(computer\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Quotation")]

    

    [Konrad Zuse](/wiki/Konrad_Zuse "Konrad Zuse"): "There is a replica of this Model in the [Museum of Traffic and Technology](/wiki/German_Museum_of_Technology "German Museum of Technology") in Berlin. Back then it didn't function well, and in that regard the replica is very reliable -- it also doesn't work well."[10]
